GAD’S HILL PLACE
HIGHAM BY ROCHESTER, KEN

body.p: As I have with great ingenuity hit upon a day that will not suit you,See To George Dolby, 26 June 1866. let us now try to hit upon one that will

I have written to Mr Chappell, Samuel Arthur Chappell (1834-1904), youngest son of Samuel Chappell, of Chappell & Co., music publishers, and a member of the firm that organised CD’s public readings. and told him that you will confer with him, and propose a time to me"to me" written above caret. that will meet the convenience of both of you.Presumably to discuss the possibility of another reading tour; see To Arthur Chappell, 2 Aug 1866, in Pilgrim Letters 11, p. 229.

What do you say to Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, the 16th, 17th and 18th.By 15 July, CD was at Gad’s Hill for the summer season and had invited 'family visitors' to stay; see To The Marquis Townshend, 15 Jul 1866, Pilgrim Letters 11, p. 223. If those days will not do, propose any others in July, except the 11th.CD came to London on 11 Jul; see To Frederic Ouvry, 11 Jul 1866, in Pilgrim Letters 11, p. 222.
